Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Cases 2003 and 2005 seem long especially due to multiple additional document requests and high complexity, region A vs B.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: Provide table of durations. Probably include lead time from submit to close. Lets compute approximate durations.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 2001: from 0900 to 1030 = 1.5 hrs. Case 2002: submit 0905, close 1100 next day? Actually events: submit 0905 same day, evaluate 0945 same day, request docs 1400 same day, approve 1000 next day? Wait timestamp: 1000 on 20240402, so time gap from request to approve ~19 hrs plus earlier events. Overall from submit to close: submit 0905 day1, close 1100 day2 => ~44 hrs? Actually close at 1100 on 20240402, so about 44 hrs. Case 2003: submit 0910 day1, close 0930 day3 => ~54 hrs 20 min? Actually close at 0930 on 20240403, so about 54 hrs 20 min. Case 2004: submit 0920 day1, close 1045 same day => 1 hr 25 min. Case 2005: submit 0925 day1, close 1430 day4 => about 79 hrs 5 min.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Thus longest is 2005 (High complexity, Region B, multiple requests). 2003 also long but less. Also note that case 2002 also longer (medium complexity) due to single request for docs but longer than low but less than high.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: We can discuss root causes: high complexity leads to multiple doc requests, causing delays; certain resources (AdjusterMike, AdjusterLisa) may have higher queue; region A vs B maybe workload differences; manager assignments etc.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: Provide suggestions: implement triage for high complexity, automate document request, route to specialized adjusters, adjust staffing, monitor resource load, use SLA thresholds. Make answer structured: 1) Lead time calculation table; 2) Identify problematic cases; 3) Attribute analysis; 4) Root cause explanations; 5) Mitigation recommendations. Make sure to be clear.
